Hello Jason,

There is=C2=A0around 30 planetary inputs together with target=
 market data and

From: jgmath2000 <jgmath2000@...>
To:=
 neat@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Fri, 5 November, 2010 13:24:16
Subject: [neat] =
Re: Financial trading with Hyperneat

=C2=A0 
Hey Peter,

I think I missed =
a step here. How is the data planetary coordinates? From the 
excel sheet, =
it looks like there are only a handful of inputs.

Jason G.

--- In neat@ya=
hoogroups.com, Peter Henry <blackprinzze@...> wrote:
>
> Hello Peter,
> 
> =
Yes it does make sense to try NEAT first, just to get a feel for this. The =
main 
>
> reason I considered hyperNEAT is because the input data would be =
planetary 
> coordinates, of which is geometric in nature. The inputs shoul=
d total no more 
> than 40, this also includes inter-market forex data. Bec=
ause future planetary 
> information is known in advance this can be used i=
n our forecasts.
> 
> Which source data Library do you feel is best for thi=
s type of task?
> 
> Peter 
> 
> 
> 
>

ng with Hyperneat
> 
> =C3=82=C2=A0 
> Hi Peter, 
> 
> I'd suggest that you=
 try regular NEAT first, HyperNEAT may not be neccessary. 
> HyperNEAT is a=
 good choice if the inputs are hundreds or thousands in number 
> and/or th=
ere is some obvious geometry in the input space that can be exploited 

> b=
y arranging the positions of the substrate nodes. For financial application=
s 
> I'd use a small set of inputs, but very preprocessed data, like what m=
ost good 

> custom indicators do, and regular NEAT. 
> 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --=
- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Wesley Tansey <tansey@> wrote:
> >
> > Peter,
> =
> 
> > I think you'd be better off familiarizing yourself with the details =
of 
> > how HyperNEAT works. Novelty Search is a different algorithm altoge=
ther, 
> > for a different class of problems. You probably should familiari=
ze 
> > yourself with the HyperNEAT algorithm before trying to design an 
>=
 > experiment. The HyperNEAT user's page has a lot of really good 
> > info=
rmation: http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/hyperNEATpage/HyperNEAT.html
> > 
> > I'm =
not familiar with the EPlex's C++ framework, but SharpNEAT does 
> > provid=
e a GUI. However, it's more of an engineer's GUI, designed to 
> > visualiz=
e your experiment after you set it up in code. I tend to find it 
> > easie=
r to just use SharpNEAT in a console application. I've written some 
> > tu=
torials on how to create a SharpNEAT experiment:
> > 
>>http://www.nashcodi=
ng.com/2010/07/17/tutorial-evolving-neural-networks-with-sharpneat-2-part-1=
/
>/
> >/
> > 
> > Hope that helps.
> > 
> > Sincerely,
> > Wesley
> >

> > >
> > > Thank=
s, Data presentation is quite important, I understand that

 is design to accept 3D data source, I can add any time frame

ultple markets, to refect external market influences.

currently a GUI interface avilable to input and output data?
> > > Is there=
 any other considerations to take into account with regards ?

a presentatation that I must adhere to?

 there is also a Novelty search Library

prated within HyperNeat?
> > >

st project quickly what is the 
> > > best way to go around this.
> > >
> >=
 > Sorry I,m a newbie to this, and would be getting techincal assistance. 
=
> > > But I do understand the external influences of the forex markets.

> > > Thanks

> >=
 > > Hi Peter,
> > > >
> > > > I think if you normalize your data (e.g., in=
 the range [-1,1]), you can
> > > > certainly give it a shot. You need to b=
e careful about overfitting to
> > > > your data, especially when all you h=
ave is daily data. Also, you 
> > > need to
> > > > be cautious about the f=
act that you'd be trading a black box.
> > > >
> > > > Sounds like a fun pr=
oject though, best of luck!

2010 10:08 PM, Peter Henry wrote:

 spreadsheet.

B to F Is the Open High Low
> > > > > Close and Volume of our target Data, =
Column E is the Close prices 
> > > this
> > > > > is what we are trying to=
 forecast for the following period. Column M
> > > > > to AP is the Astrolo=
gical Data that would be used as inputs, Note the
> > > > > Astro engine ca=
n Generate data indefinitely into the future, this
> > > > > can be helpful=
 in our forecasts

> > > > > I hope this is clear
> > > > > Thanks=
 RegardsPeter

nse. I'm doing it for fun interest and personal

s, I'm more fascinated by the prospect both Astro 
> > > and
> > > > > AI w=
orking together.
> > > > >
> > > > > The Swiss Astro Engine is freely avail=
able and can generate planetary
> > > > > information in real time. I would=
 initially start with daily price
> > > > > data then scale it up to Monthl=
y or Hours and minutes.

lanetary locations together with the
> > > > > close prices of target data.=

be you could fill us in a little more. For starters, what's an

tro Engine? What kind of intervals are you trading? What are the
> > > > > =
inputs/outputs going to be? What is your data set size? How are you
> > > >=
 > going to prevent over-fitting?
> > > > >
> > > > > 1. I think it's impos=
sible to say without knowing more.
> > > > > 2. Not theoretically. I suppos=
e at some point, your net gets too slow
> > > > > to be practical.
> > > > =
> 3. The EPlex C++ framework:
> > > > > http://eplex.cs.ucf.edu/software.ht=
ml#gaucij_HyperNEAT
> > > > > Also, Colin Green's SharpNEAT (C#) framework:=

> > > > > https://sites.google.com/site/sharpneat/
> > > > >
> > > > > Al!=
 so, are you doing this for fun or profit? If you're doing it for
> > > > >=
 profit, there are a ton of other considerations that you have to take
> > =
> > > into account, particularly regarding trading costs and regulations.
>=
 > > > >
> > > > > Wesley
> > > > >

enry wrote:

to create trading indicator and systems using

r the following questions or simply give
> > > > >> there options
> > > > >=
>
> > > > >> 1, Does anyone think the HyperNEAT is suitable for such a task=

> > > > >> 2, Is there any restrictions on the amount of input data that c=
an be
> > > > >> used.
> > > > >> 3, What is the best HyperNEAT Software Li=
braries available
> > > > >>
> > > > >> The engine is going to be used for =
forecast forex prices using Astro
> > > > >> and Inter-market data. HyperNe=
at to be used to work out 
> > > relationships
> > > > >> and predict price=
s,
> > > > >>
> > > > >> Thanks in advance I will share any results with gr=
oup
> > > > >>
> > > > >> Peter
> > > > >>

> > > > >
